newsitem.title: THAILAND: Thai baht falls, resignation rumour denied.
newsitem.headline: Thai baht falls, resignation rumour denied.

text.p: The Thai baht fell against the dollar on Thursday after rumours the head of the central bank was quitting, but a Bank of Thailand official denied the speculation.
Foreign exchange dealers blamed on the currency's fall on speculation that central bank governor Rerngchai Marakanond might resign.
The rumours followed reports in some small Thai business newspapers that Rerngchai might have prepared his resignation letter and could submit it to the finance minister later on Thursday.
The baht fell to 25.960/965 against the dollar from around 25.945/950 late on Wednesday on the rumour, dealers said.
"The rumours have affected the baht. People are moving to the dollar," said a senior dealer with a foreign bank.
However, the central bank later denied Rerngchai would resign.
"I have been asked to categorically deny these rumours in the market," a senior Bank of Thailand official told Reuters.

The baht, which came under speculative attack late last year and in February due to pressure from a strong dollar and devaluation rumours, had recently steadied after authorities firmly ruled out devaluation.
The Thai stock market remained mostly unaffected by the talk, with brokers saying they were more concerned about the health of finance companies and high interest rates.
Two Moody's Investors Service officials are in Bangkok this week and have met Finance Minister Amnuay Viravan and central bank officials to gather data on the Thai economy.
The agency had last month put Thailand's long term debt rating on watch for a possible downgrade. The Moody's officials' plans for gathering more data on Thursday were not available.
Newspaper reports speculated that Rerngchai might resign in protest over the government's suspension of three Bank of Thailand officials, including deputy governor Jaroong Nookhwun, on Wednesday.

The officials were suspended in connection with their failure to bring former executives of the ailing Bangkok Bank of Commerce to court for violations of the Banking Act, a government spokesman said.
Prosecutors last month said they were forced to drop a government case against the executives because a one-year statute of limitations had expired.
